Create prediction accuracy plot

Source: R/visualization.R
create_accuracy_plot.Rd

Creates a bar plot showing prediction accuracy for different methods and conditions.

Usage

create_accuracy_plot(
  evaluation_results,
  method = c("direct", "svm"),
  title = NULL,
  color_palette = NULL,
  verbose = TRUE
)

Arguments

evaluation_results

List containing evaluation results from evaluate_predictions().

method

Character string specifying which method to plot ("direct" or "svm").

title

Character string for plot title. Default is NULL.

color_palette

Character vector. Colors to use for the plot (default: NULL, uses default palette).

verbose

Logical. Whether to print progress messages (default: TRUE).

Value

A ggplot object containing the accuracy plot.

Details

This function visualizes the prediction accuracy results from the evaluate_predictions function. It creates a bar plot showing the accuracy of predictions across different samples or conditions.

The function processes data differently based on the method parameter:

  • "direct": Uses accuracy data from direct similarity-based predictions

  • "svm": Uses accuracy data from Support Vector Machine predictions

The workflow includes:

  1. Validating input parameters and checking for required data

  2. Extracting the appropriate accuracy data based on the method

  3. Creating a bar plot with accuracy percentages

  4. Adding percentage labels above each bar

  5. Applying custom colors if provided

The resulting plot displays samples on the x-axis and accuracy values on the y-axis, with each bar representing the percentage of correctly predicted cells for that sample. Text labels show the exact percentage values above each bar.

The function includes comprehensive error handling to catch missing data, invalid parameters, or processing issues with informative error messages.

Examples

# Example with mock evaluation results
# Create mock evaluation results structure
evaluation_results <- list(
    direct = list(
        accuracy = data.frame(
            sample = c("Sample1", "Sample2", "Sample3", "Sample4"),
            accuracy = c(85.2, 78.5, 92.1, 88.7)
        )
    ),
    svm = list(
        accuracy = data.frame(
            sample = c("Sample1", "Sample2", "Sample3", "Sample4"),
            accuracy = c(87.3, 81.2, 94.5, 90.1)
        )
    )
)

# Create accuracy plot for direct method
plot_direct <- create_accuracy_plot(evaluation_results, method = "direct")
#> Error in create_accuracy_plot(evaluation_results, method = "direct"): direct_accuracy not found in evaluation_results

# Create accuracy plot for SVM method
plot_svm <- create_accuracy_plot(evaluation_results, method = "svm")
#> Error in create_accuracy_plot(evaluation_results, method = "svm"): svm_accuracy not found in evaluation_results
